chapter_name: Economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis
text:
| This article was **imported from the CIA's _World Factbook_**. Please help
rewrite this article.  
---|---  
The St. Kitts 'Sugar Train' in 1912 used to transport sugarcane

The **economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis** has traditionally depended on the
growing and processing of sugar cane; decreasing world prices have hurt the
industry in recent years. Tourism, export-oriented manufacturing, and offshore
banking activity have assumed larger roles in Saint Kitts and Nevis. Most food
is imported. The government has undertaken a program designed to revitalize
the faltering sugar sector. It is also working to improve revenue collection
in order to better fund social programs. In 1997, some leaders in Nevis were
urging separation from Saint Kitts on the basis that Nevis was paying far more
in taxes than it was receiving in government services, but the vote on
secession failed in August 1998. In late September 1998, Hurricane Georges
caused approximately $445 million in damages and limited GDP growth for the
year.

The economy of St. Kitts and Nevis experienced strong growth for most of the
1990s but hurricanes in 1998 and 1999 contributed to a sharp slowdown. Real
economic growth was 0.75% in 2002 after a decline of 4.3% in 2001. The economy
experienced a mixed performance during 2002, with some sectors experiencing
positive growth while others experienced varying levels of decline. The
construction sector recorded a 4.51% decline, manufacturing and hotels and
restaurants also recorded significant declines of 4.01 and 9.89% respectively,
and sugar production fell by 5.1%. Significant new investment in tourism,
including a 648-room Marriott hotel and convention center that opened in
December 2002, as well as continued government efforts to diversify the
economy, are expected to improve economic performance. Consumer prices have
risen marginally over the past few years. The inflation rate was 3–4% for most
of the 1990s.

St. Kitts and Nevis is a member of the Eastern Caribbean Currency Union (ECCU)
The Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB) issues a common currency (the East
Caribbean dollar) for all members of the ECCU. The ECCB also manages monetary
policy, and regulates and supervises commercial banking activities in its
member countries. There is an extensive parallel economy denominated in US$,
which is the de facto currency for many business transactions.

St. Kitts is a member of the Eastern Caribbean Telecommunications (ECTEL)
authority, which is developing the regulations to liberalize the
telecommunications sector in the region by 2004.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis has historically relied on the cultivation and processing of sugar cane, but declining global sugar prices have negatively impacted this industry in recent years.
• Tourism, export-oriented manufacturing, and offshore banking have become increasingly significant sectors in the economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis.
• The country imports most of its food supplies, indicating a reliance on external sources for food security.
• The government has initiated a program aimed at revitalizing the struggling sugar sector to restore its economic contribution.
• Efforts are underway by the government to enhance revenue collection mechanisms to better finance social programs within the federation.

• In 1997, certain leaders from Nevis advocated for secession from Saint Kitts, citing a disproportionate tax burden on Nevis relative to government services received; however, a secession vote held in August 1998 did not pass.
• Hurricane Georges struck in late September 1998, causing approximately $445 million in damages and constraining GDP growth for that year.
• The economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis experienced robust growth throughout most of the 1990s, but the hurricanes in 1998 and 1999 led to a significant economic slowdown.
• Real economic growth was recorded at 0.75% in 2002 following a 4.3% contraction in 2001.

• The economic performance in 2002 was mixed, with some sectors growing while others declined; specifically, the construction sector shrank by 4.51%, manufacturing declined by 4.01%, hotels and restaurants fell by 9.89%, and sugar production decreased by 5.1%.

• Major new investments in tourism, including the opening of a 648-room Marriott hotel and convention center in December 2002, alongside ongoing government diversification efforts, are anticipated to enhance future economic performance.
• Consumer prices have increased marginally over recent years, with inflation rates ranging between 3% and 4% for most of the 1990s.
• Saint Kitts and Nevis is a member of the Eastern Caribbean Currency Union (ECCU), which uses the East Caribbean dollar as a common currency issued by the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB).
• The ECCB is responsible for managing monetary policy and regulating and supervising commercial banking activities across ECCU member countries.
• There exists a substantial parallel economy in Saint Kitts and Nevis that operates primarily in United States dollars, which serve as the de facto currency for many business transactions.

• Saint Kitts is a member of the Eastern Caribbean Telecommunications Authority (ECTEL), which is tasked with developing regulations to liberalize the telecommunications sector in the region by the year 2004.

chapter_name: Economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis
text:
According to the CIA World Factbook the main industry is tourism. Tourists,
mainly Americans, come to the island via cruise ships (via Port Zante in
Basseterre), air travel (via Robert L Bradshaw International Airport), and the
private airport and private dock (for private yachts).

The tourism industry is unique in that it relies on both long term and short
term visitors. Short term visitors are generally Americans, Canadians, and
other CARICOM countries who come via cruise ship for the day or via Robert L
Bradshaw airport for short term stay. Long term visitors are mostly Americans
and Canadians that are staying for an average of 2.5-3 years on the island for
vet school or medical school. The vet school on the island is Ross University
School of Veterinary Medicine.

The tourism sector was badly hit by the effects of the hurricanes in 1998 and
1999. The country had just started to rebuild after Georges in 1998 when Lenny
created substantial damage in 1999. The Port Zante complex, where the pier and
terminal buildings are located, suffered serious damage. In Nevis, the only
large hotel was forced to close for 6 months, resulting in lay-offs of staff
(although many were employed to re-landscape devastated gardens) and decreased
government revenue. Overall visitor arrivals, both of those staying over and
those on cruise ship calls, fell about 15 percent in 1999, with a resulting
decrease in visitor expenditure from the 1998 figure of US$75.7 million.

A unique point of interest is that the island of St. Kitts possesses the only
remaining active railway in the West Indies. This was built to move sugarcane
around, and part of the railway remains in use for tourist tours.

St. Kitts is also home to Brimstone Hill Fortress, a UNESCO world heritage
site
openai_summarised_points: • According to the CIA World Factbook, the primary industry in Saint Kitts and Nevis is tourism, which attracts mainly American visitors.

• Tourists access the islands through multiple transportation modes: cruise ships docking at Port Zante in Basseterre, air travel via Robert L Bradshaw International Airport, and private arrivals through a private airport and private dock designated for yachts.
• The tourism industry in Saint Kitts and Nevis is characterized by a dual reliance on both short-term and long-term visitors.

• Short-term visitors predominantly include Americans, Canadians, and nationals from other CARICOM countries who arrive either for day visits via cruise ships or for brief stays via Robert L Bradshaw International Airport.
• Long-term visitors are primarily Americans and Canadians who stay on the island for an average duration of 2.5 to 3 years, mainly to attend veterinary or medical schools.
• Ross University School of Veterinary Medicine, located on the island, is a significant institution attracting long-term visitors for veterinary education.
• The tourism sector experienced severe setbacks due to hurricanes in consecutive years: Hurricane Georges in 1998 and Hurricane Lenny in 1999.
• The country had begun recovery efforts after Hurricane Georges in 1998 when Hurricane Lenny inflicted substantial additional damage in 1999.
• The Port Zante complex, which houses the cruise ship pier and terminal buildings, sustained serious damage during these hurricanes.

• On the island of Nevis, the only large hotel was compelled to close for six months following the hurricanes, which led to staff layoffs; however, many former employees were subsequently hired to assist in re-landscaping the devastated gardens.
• The damage and disruptions caused by the hurricanes resulted in a decline in government revenue linked to the tourism sector.
• Overall visitor arrivals, including both overnight guests and cruise ship passengers, decreased by approximately 15 percent in 1999 compared to previous years.
• Correspondingly, visitor expenditure dropped from US$75.7 million in 1998 to a lower figure in 1999 due to the decline in tourism activity.
• A unique feature of Saint Kitts is that it possesses the only remaining active railway in the West Indies, originally constructed to transport sugarcane.
• Part of this historic railway is currently utilized for tourist tours, adding a distinctive attraction to the island’s tourism offerings.
• Saint Kitts is also home to Brimstone Hill Fortress, which is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, further enhancing the cultural and historical appeal of the destination.

chapter_name: Economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis
text:
Of the islands' total land area, about 39% is devoted to crops. The principal
agricultural product of St. Kitts is sugarcane; peanuts are now the second
crop. On Nevis, sea island cotton and coconuts are the major commodities.
Sweet potatoes, onions, tomatoes, cabbages, carrots, and breadfruit are grown
for local consumption on both islands, mostly by individual smallholders. In
2001, agricultural products accounted for about 18.5% of total imports by
value and 11.2% of exports; the government has embarked on a program to
substitute for food imports.

Sugar estate lands were nationalized in 1975, and the sugar factory was
purchased by the government the following year. The output of raw sugar
slumped between 1986 and 1989, and as a result the government entered into a
management agreement with Booke and Tate of Great Britain in August 1991; a
World Bank loan of US$1.9 million was utilized to provide financial stability.
Sugar production in 1999 was estimated at 197,000 tons. Faced with a sugar
industry that was finding it increasingly difficult to earn a profit, the
Government of St. Kitts and Nevis embarked on a program to diversify the
agricultural sector and stimulate the development of other sectors of the
economy, particularly tourism. In July 2005, sugar production ceased.
openai_summarised_points: • Approximately 39% of the total land area of Saint Kitts and Nevis is dedicated to crop cultivation, reflecting the significance of agriculture in land use on the islands.
• The principal agricultural product on the island of Saint Kitts is sugarcane, which has historically been the dominant crop in the region.
• Peanuts have emerged as the second most important crop on Saint Kitts, indicating diversification within the island’s agricultural sector.
• On the island of Nevis, the major agricultural commodities are sea island cotton and coconuts, highlighting a difference in crop specialization between the two islands.

• Both islands cultivate a variety of vegetables and fruits for local consumption, including sweet potatoes, onions, tomatoes, cabbages, carrots, and breadfruit, primarily grown by individual smallholders rather than large commercial farms.
• In 2001, agricultural products constituted approximately 18.5% of the total value of imports into Saint Kitts and Nevis, demonstrating the sector’s role in trade and food supply.
• The same year, agricultural products accounted for 11.2% of the country’s exports by value, underscoring agriculture’s contribution to the export economy.

• The government of Saint Kitts and Nevis has initiated a program aimed at substituting food imports with locally produced agricultural goods, reflecting a policy focus on increasing self-sufficiency.
• In 1975, the government nationalized sugar estate lands, marking a significant shift in ownership and control of the sugar industry.
• The following year, in 1976, the government purchased the sugar factory, consolidating state control over sugar production infrastructure.
• Between 1986 and 1989, the output of raw sugar experienced a significant decline, prompting concerns about the viability of the sugar industry.

• In response to the decline, the government entered into a management agreement with Booke and Tate, a company based in Great Britain, in August 1991 to improve the management and performance of the sugar industry.
• To support this initiative, the World Bank provided a loan of US$1.9 million aimed at stabilizing the financial situation of the sugar sector.
• By 1999, sugar production was estimated at 197,000 tons, indicating the scale of the industry at the end of the 20th century.

• Facing increasing difficulties in maintaining profitability in the sugar industry, the Government of Saint Kitts and Nevis began implementing a program to diversify the agricultural sector and stimulate growth in other economic sectors, particularly tourism.
• In July 2005, sugar production on the islands ceased entirely, marking the end of an era for the traditional sugar industry in Saint Kitts and Nevis.

chapter_name: Economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis
text:
Pasture areas are small, covering some 2.7% of the islands. Pangola and
Bermuda grasses provide the bulk of the fodder. Estimates of livestock in 2001
were sheep, 14,000; goats, 14,400; cattle, 4,300 head; and pigs, 4,000.
openai_summarised_points: • Pasture areas in Saint Kitts and Nevis are limited, covering approximately 2.7% of the total land area of the islands.
• The primary types of grasses used for fodder in the islands are Pangola grass and Bermuda grass, which constitute the bulk of animal feed.
• Livestock estimates from the year 2001 indicate the presence of 14,000 sheep on the islands.
• In 2001, there were approximately 14,400 goats reported in Saint Kitts and Nevis.
• The cattle population was estimated at 4,300 head in 2001.
• Pig numbers were recorded at around 4,000 in the year 2001.

chapter_name: Economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis
text:
Fishing is a traditional occupation that has not expanded to any great extent;
the catch in 2000 was 257 tons (down from 620 tons in 1990). Some exports
(primarily lobsters) are made to the Netherlands Antilles and Puerto Rico;
fisheries exports totaled US$245,000 in 2000. Fish is caught by traditional
methods such as beach-seining, pot and trap fishing & hand-lining. The catch
is not enough to satisfy local demand for fish. Large quantities of dried,
salted and smoked fish, as well as frozen are imported from Canada and the
United States.
openai_summarised_points: • Fishing in Saint Kitts and Nevis is a traditional occupation that has not experienced significant expansion over time.
• The total fish catch in the year 2000 was recorded at 257 tons, representing a decline from 620 tons in 1990.
• Some fisheries exports, primarily consisting of lobsters, are shipped to the Netherlands Antilles and Puerto Rico.
• The total value of fisheries exports in 2000 amounted to US$245,000.
• Fish are caught using traditional methods including beach-seining, pot and trap fishing, and hand-lining.
• The local fish catch is insufficient to meet the domestic demand for fish in Saint Kitts and Nevis.
• Consequently, large quantities of dried, salted, smoked, and frozen fish are imported from Canada and the United States to satisfy local consumption needs.

chapter_name: Economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis
text:
Both islands have small stands of virgin tropical forest, with palms,
poincianas, and palmettos. About 11% of the land area consists of forests.
Imports of forest products nearly reached US$1.8 million in 2000.
openai_summarised_points: • Both islands of Saint Kitts and Nevis contain small stands of virgin tropical forest characterized by the presence of palms, poincianas, and palmettos.
• Approximately 11% of the total land area of Saint Kitts and Nevis is covered by forests.
• In the year 2000, imports of forest products into Saint Kitts and Nevis nearly reached a value of US$1.8 million.

chapter_name: Economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis
text:
The mining sector played a minor role in St. Kitts and Nevis. No commercially
valuable mineral deposits have been found on Saint Kitts. Hence mining and
quarrying activities are limited to earthen materials. Presently, there is
only one quarry on St. Kitts and multiple quarries on Nevis. Raking of salt,
the country's fourth-leading industry, was done from time to time. Local
quarrying of some materials was used to supplement the construction industry.
In 2000, output for sand and gravel was 214,700 tons, up from 50,389 in 1996;
crushed stone output was 121,226 tons.
openai_summarised_points: • The mining sector has historically played a minor role in the economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis.
• No commercially valuable mineral deposits have been discovered on the island of Saint Kitts.
• Due to the absence of significant mineral resources, mining and quarrying activities are restricted to the extraction of earthen materials.
• Currently, there is only one operational quarry on Saint Kitts, whereas the island of Nevis hosts multiple quarries.
• Salt raking, recognized as the country's fourth-leading industry, has been conducted intermittently rather than continuously.
• Locally quarried materials have been primarily utilized to support and supplement the construction industry within the country.
• In the year 2000, the production output for sand and gravel reached 214,700 tons, showing a significant increase from 50,389 tons recorded in 1996.
• Crushed stone production in 2000 amounted to 121,226 tons, contributing to the overall quarrying output.

chapter_name: Economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis
text:
Industry accounted for 26% of GDP in 2001. The principal manufacturing plant
and largest industrial employer is the St. Kitts Sugar Manufacturing Corp., a
government enterprise; it grinds and processes sugarcane for export. The Carib
brewery on St. Kitts makes beer for local consumption. Cotton is ginned and
baled on Nevis. Electronic plants produce switches, calculators, car radios,
and pocket radios. Other industries are clothing and shoe manufacturing. These
provide a much-needed alternative to agricultural employment, particularly for
women.

The manufacturing suffered a decline in 1998 due to Hurricane Georges. As a
result of diversification and expansion, St. Kitts and Nevis has transformed
small electronics plants into the largest electronics assembly industry in the
Eastern Caribbean. Its apparel assembly industry has also become very
successful in recent years. Garment manufacturing has expanded since the
mid-1990s and now accounts for a large share of export earnings. Upgrading the
Port Zante harbor complex in Basseterre enables large container ships to call,
further enhancing St. Kitts' attractiveness as an offshore manufacturing base.
Manufactured exports were valued at US$20 million in 1998 and 1999, suggesting
that this sector was the least affected by hurricane damage.

There were four major industrial sites in St. Kitts and Nevis in 2000: C. A.
Paul Southwell Industrial Park, Bourkes Industrial Estate, Canada Industrial
Estate, and Prospect Industrial Estate. Port Zante is the main seaport.
openai_summarised_points: • Industry contributed 26% to the GDP of Saint Kitts and Nevis in 2001, indicating its significant role in the national economy.

• The principal manufacturing plant and largest industrial employer is the St. Kitts Sugar Manufacturing Corporation, a government-owned enterprise responsible for grinding and processing sugarcane primarily for export purposes.
• The Carib Brewery, located on St. Kitts, produces beer intended for local consumption within the federation.
• On the island of Nevis, cotton is processed through ginning and baling operations, supporting the agricultural-industrial linkage.
• Electronic manufacturing plants produce a variety of products including switches, calculators, car radios, and pocket radios, contributing to the diversification of the industrial sector.
• Additional industries include clothing and shoe manufacturing, which provide essential alternative employment opportunities to the agricultural sector, particularly benefiting women workers.
• The manufacturing sector experienced a decline in 1998 as a direct consequence of the damage caused by Hurricane Georges.
• Following this setback, diversification and expansion efforts transformed small electronics plants into the largest electronics assembly industry in the Eastern Caribbean region.

• The apparel assembly industry has seen notable success since the mid-1990s, with garment manufacturing expanding significantly and now accounting for a substantial portion of the country’s export earnings.
• Upgrades to the Port Zante harbor complex in Basseterre have enabled the accommodation of large container ships, thereby enhancing St. Kitts’ appeal as an offshore manufacturing hub.

• Manufactured exports were valued at US$20 million in both 1998 and 1999, indicating that the manufacturing sector was relatively resilient and the least affected by the hurricane damage compared to other sectors.

• In the year 2000, there were four major industrial sites in Saint Kitts and Nevis: C. A. Paul Southwell Industrial Park, Bourkes Industrial Estate, Canada Industrial Estate, and Prospect Industrial Estate.
• Port Zante serves as the main seaport for the federation, playing a critical role in facilitating industrial exports and imports.

chapter_name: Economy of Saint Kitts and Nevis
text:
purchasing power parity \- $726 million (2006 est.)

**GDP - real growth rate:** 6% (2007 est.)

**GDP - per capita:** purchasing power parity - $8,200 (2005 est.)

**GDP - composition by sector:** _agriculture:_ 3.5% _industry:_ 25.8%
_services:_ 70.7%(2001)

**Inflation rate (consumer prices):** 8.7% (2005 est.)

**Labor force:** 18,172 (June 1995)

**Unemployment rate:** 4.5% (1997)

**Budget:** _revenues:_ $64.1 million

_expenditures:_ $73.3 million, including capital expenditures of $10.4 million
(1997 est.)

**Industries:** sugar processing, tourism, cotton, salt, copra, clothing,
footwear, beverages

**Electricity - production:** 125 million kWh (2005)

**Electricity - production by source:** _fossil fuel:_ 100% _hydro:_ 0%
_nuclear:_ 0% _other:_ 0% (1998)

**Electricity - consumption:** 116.3 million kWh (2005)

**Electricity - exports:** 0 kWh (2005)

**Electricity - imports:** 0 kWh (2005)

**Agriculture - products:** sugarcane, rice, yams, vegetables, bananas; fish

**Exports:** $42 million (1998)

**Exports - commodities:** machinery, food, electronics, beverages, tobacco

**Exports - partners:** US 61.9%, Canada 9.4%, Netherlands 6.6%, Azerbaijan 5%
(2006)

**Imports:** $383 million (2006)

**Imports - commodities:** machinery, manufactures, food, fuels

**Imports - partners:** US 49.5%, Trinidad and Tobago 13.3%, UK 4.5% (2006)

**Debt - external:** $314 million (2004)

**Economic aid - recipient:** $3.52 million (2005)

**Currency:** 1 East Caribbean dollar (EC$) = 100 cents

**Exchange rates:** East Caribbean dollars per US dollar - 2.7 (2007), 2.7
(2006), 2.7 (2005), 2.7 (2004), 2.7 (2003)

**Fiscal year:** calendar year
openai_summarised_points: • The purchasing power parity (PPP) of Saint Kitts and Nevis was estimated at $726 million in 2006.
• The real GDP growth rate of Saint Kitts and Nevis was estimated at 6% in 2007.
• The GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity was approximately $8,200 in 2005.
• The GDP composition by sector in 2001 was as follows: agriculture accounted for 3.5%, industry for 25.8%, and services for 70.7%.
• The inflation rate, measured by consumer prices, was estimated at 8.7% in 2005.
• The labor force of Saint Kitts and Nevis was recorded as 18,172 individuals in June 1995.
• The unemployment rate was estimated at 4.5% in 1997.
• The national budget for 1997 showed revenues of $64.1 million and expenditures of $73.3 million, which included capital expenditures of $10.4 million.
• Key industries in Saint Kitts and Nevis include sugar processing, tourism, cotton, salt, copra, clothing, footwear, and beverages.
• Electricity production was 125 million kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 2005.
• In 1998, electricity production was entirely from fossil fuels (100%), with no contribution from hydro, nuclear, or other sources.
• Electricity consumption in 2005 was 116.3 million kWh.
• There were no electricity exports or imports recorded in 2005, both at 0 kWh.
• Agricultural products include sugarcane, rice, yams, vegetables, bananas, and fish.
• Total exports were valued at $42 million in 1998.
• Export commodities comprised machinery, food, electronics, beverages, and tobacco.
• The main export partners in 2006 were the United States (61.9%), Canada (9.4%), the Netherlands (6.6%), and Azerbaijan (5%).
• Imports totaled $383 million in 2006.
• Imported commodities included machinery, manufactures, food, and fuels.
• The principal import partners in 2006 were the United States (49.5%), Trinidad and Tobago (13.3%), and the United Kingdom (4.5%).
• External debt was recorded at $314 million in 2004.
• Economic aid received amounted to $3.52 million in 2005.
• The currency used is the East Caribbean dollar (EC$), with 1 East Caribbean dollar equal to 100 cents.
• The exchange rate of East Caribbean dollars per US dollar remained stable at 2.7 from 2003 through 2007.
• The fiscal year for Saint Kitts and Nevis follows the calendar year.
